title: 113_s2701
content: The Act titled "Stopping Illegal Obamacare Subsidies Act" prohibits automatic enrollment in health plans by American Health Benefit Exchanges until inconsistencies outlined in a June 2014 report are resolved by the Inspector General of the Department of Health and Human Services. SEC. 3. PROCESS FOR APPLICATIONS WITH INCONSISTENCIES. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will make public the steps to resolve inconsistencies in eligibility for healthcare programs within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Monitoring progress methods will also be implemented within the same timeframe. The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services will resolve inconsistencies in eligibility for healthcare programs within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Monitoring methods will be made public to track progress in resolving inconsistencies. Suspension of premium assistance tax credits and cost-sharing programs for plan year 2015 until inconsistencies are resolved. Resumption of programs contingent on progress monitoring methods being made public. Suspension of premium assistance tax credits and cost-sharing programs for plan year 2015 until inconsistencies related to invalid social security numbers are resolved. Resumption of programs contingent on declarations from the Commissioner of the Social Security Administration and the Inspector General of the Department of Health and Human Services. The sharing programs will resume after the Commissioner of the Social Security Administration confirms resolution of invalid social security number inconsistencies and the Inspector General of the Department of Health and Human Services confirms resolution of all inconsistencies. Requests for additional information may be made if applicant information contains inconsistencies. Human Services confirms resolution of all inconsistencies in applicant information for enrollment in a qualified health plan on State or Federal Exchanges. Requests for additional information may be made within a 90-day period if inconsistencies are present. During this period, individuals may be enrolled in a qualified health plan but cannot participate in premium payments. During the inconsistency period, the Secretary may request additional information from the individual, who has 90 days to provide it. The individual can be enrolled in a qualified health plan but cannot participate in the premium assistance credit program or reduced cost-sharing program. During the inconsistency period, the Secretary may request additional information from the individual, who has 90 days to provide it. If the applicant fails to submit the requested information, they may not be eligible for benefits under the assistance credit program or reduced cost-sharing program. During the inconsistency period, if an individual fails to submit requested information, they may be withdrawn from the premium assistance credit program and reduced cost-sharing program. Eligible individuals will retroactively receive benefits for the period. During the inconsistency period, if an individual fails to submit requested information, they may be withdrawn from the premium assistance credit program and reduced cost-sharing program. The applicant will be disenrolled at the end of the inconsistency period and must re-enroll in a qualified plan. Notification of disenrollment will be sent to the health insurance issuer. During the inconsistency period, if an individual fails to provide required information, they will be disenrolled from the premium assistance credit program and reduced cost-sharing program. The Secretary will notify the health insurance issuer of the disenrollment, and the applicant must re-enroll in a qualified health plan with accurate information during the next open enrollment period. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "inconsistencies" refer to differences in self-attested information provided by an applicant for health plan enrollment and the data received from the Federal Data Services Hub or other sources, including citizenship and income. The curr_chunk discusses discrepancies in data received from Medicaid or CHIP plans and the Federal Data Services Hub, including citizenship, income, employer-sponsored coverage, incarceration status, and other factors affecting eligibility for financial assistance programs under the Affordable Care Act. The curr_chunk defines "inconsistency period" as a 90-day period following the notice of an inconsistency sent to the applicant.
